conversation.text: Hello! Are you ready to begin? For this recipe, you'll need all-purpose flour and vital wheat gluten.
The amount of flour depends on the recipe you are using. But most bread recipes won't need more than a few teaspoons of vital wheat gluten.
For your recipe that requires bread flour, measure out the same amount of all-purpose flour instead. Use a separate bowl from the other ingredients.
evidence: Measure out the all-purpose flour for your recipe

conversation.text: I've measured the flour. What do I do next?
How many cups of flour did you measure out? You will need one teaspoon of vital what gluten per cup of flour.
evidence: Add one teaspoon vital wheat gluten per cup of flour

conversation.text: I will add the amount accordingly.
Do you have any whole wheat flour? You can add up to 1/2 teaspoon as a binding agent and for a slightly nutty flavor.
evidence: Add a small amount of whole wheat flour

conversation.text: Can I add more than 1/2 teaspoon?
You shouldn't add more than that, otherwise the total volume of flour will be affected.
Sift all the ingredients together. They can be used as a substitute for bread flour in your recipe!
Is it any different from normal bread flour
The flour substitute gluten will make the bread a little denser and stronger. You might get a different texture from what you expect.
evidence: The gluten in the new flour substitute will give the final product a denser, "stronger" bread

conversation.text: Congratulations! You have successfully completed this cooking task.
Thank you again for the help.

procedure.summary: Buy or order vital wheat gluten.
procedure.description: For this recipe, you'll need only two ingredients: all-purpose flour and vital wheat gluten. All-purpose flour can be purchased at nearly any grocery store. However, you may need to make a trip to a health food store or a baking supply store to find vital wheat gluten. Alternatively, if you can stand to wait, vital wheat gluten is easily available for order online. Either way, it is not especially expensive — a small bag should cost less than $10. You won't need more than a few teaspoons of vital wheat gluten for most bread recipes.

procedure.summary: Measure out the all-purpose flour for your recipe.
procedure.description: Look at the recipe to see how much bread flour is required. Measure out this much all-purpose flour instead. Pour this flour into a mixing bowl separate from the other ingredients.

procedure.summary: Add one teaspoon vital wheat gluten per cup of flour.
procedure.description: This converts all-purpose flour to a form that can be used just like bread flour. This ratio scales proportionally. For instance, if your recipe calls for 2 1/2 cups of bread flour, you would add 2 1/2 teaspoons vital wheat gluten to 2 1/2 cups of all-purpose flour.

procedure.summary: Add a small amount of whole wheat flour.
procedure.description: This step isn't essential, but a little wheat flour works well as a binding agent and gives the bread a subtle "nutty" flavor. Add no more than 1/2 teaspoon per cup of all-purpose flour so as not to affect the total volume of your dry ingredients.

Sift the ingredients above together in the bowl. Once they are well incorporated, you will be left with a substance you can use in place of bread flour. The gluten in the new flour substitute will give the final product a denser, "stronger" bread than you would have otherwise. Don't be alarmed if your bread turns out with a slightly different texture than it had before.
